subject: Re: [junit] expensive setup which is definitely only required   once
msgSnippet: ... 1. The data is in the test where I can see it, rather than in a file. 2. Using data in a file means worrying about where the files are on the file system
messageBody:
>So said Tung Wai Yip on 4/7/2003 --------------------

>Can you explain why is 1. better?

1. The data is in the test where I can see it, rather than in a file.
2. Using data in a file means worrying about where the files are on the file system when executing the tests.
3. What if I need to execute the tests on a file system that doesn't understand "g:/myCsvFiles"? (Yes, there are solutions, but none as easy as not having to worry about it.)
4. Tests that require the file system are slower.
5. Cleaning up the file system is asynchronous (from what I can tell) and unreliable to do in tests that execute at a rate of dozens per second.

>Let say I want to test some higher granularity methods like
>
> csv.findDuplicates()
> csv.convertToXML()
> csv.calcStatistics()
>
>how would you propose to do it without reading a CSV file?

Processing the data is separate from reading/writing the data. This implies two separate classes.

csvDataProcessor.findDuplicates(new CsvFileReader(fileName));
...

This is exactly how XSL transformers work: transforming XML and reading/writing XML are separate concerns.

Take care.
